questions.question: For what population size is an urban Primary Health Centre (PHC) typically intended?
questions.explanation: population of around 50,000 people. Type of primary health centre Plain population Hilly & tribal population Rural PHC 1 per 30,000 1 per 20,000 Urban PHC 1 per 50,000 - Multispeciality UPHC/Polyclinic 1 per 2-3 lakh - Incorrect Options: Options B, C & D: A U-PHC is not intended for such a large population as it might not effectively serve the healthcare needs of the population. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th edition, Page 307

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes Ayushman Bharat?

options.B: Aim is to achieve universal health coverage in India
options.C: Covers only tertiary health care centres
options.D: Cashless, paperless service by only government hospitals

questions.explanation: Bharat scheme, also known as Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana, aims to achieve universal health coverage in India. Ayushman Bharat - Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PMJAY): An initiative launched in 2018 (Option A ruled out) by Govt. of India to achieve UHC (Option B) Provides all the elements, including NCDS, in primary care. Benefits: Coverage : up to INR 5 lakh per family per year for secondary and tertiary care hospitalization. (Option C ruled out) There is no restriction on the number of family members. Cashless access across the country (Option D ruled out) All pre-existing conditions covered Covers the cost of treatment, up to 3 days of pre-hospitalization and 15 days of post-hospitalization follow-up care. Beneficiaries: Vulnerable and poor populations based on the Socio-Economic Caste Census ( SECC ) database. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition Page 719

questions.question: How many individuals are allocated to one ASHA worker for the population in rural areas?
questions.explanation: elected by a village panchayat and under the supervision of a medical officer. The existing population norm is 1/1000. The proposed population norm is 2/1000. ASHA should be: A resident of the same village A married/divorced/single woman Preferably from the age group 25-45 Educated up to class 10 One ASHA for 1000 population/per habitation Reference: K.Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition, Page 700-701

questions.question: Which of the following is not considered a pillar of primary health care?
questions.explanation: Equitable distribution (Option D ruled out): Equitable distribution of health services irrespective of their socio-economic status. Intersectoral coordination (Option B ruled out): Involves collaboration from other sectors like agriculture, education, etc. Maintains good health. Appropriate technology (Option c ruled out): Use of technology that is accessible, affordable, and suitable for the community Eg: ORS VVM (Vaccine Vial Monitor): Heat sensitive label Shakir tape: Malnutrition grading Kangaroo mother care: Preterm care Community participation: Ensure the participation of the community in planning, implementing and maintaining. For the promotion and maintenance of their health. Eg: ASHA workers are residents of the same community. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition Pg: 693-694

questions.question: Which entity is responsible for overseeing the school health programs?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Primary health center Explanation: Primary health centers (PHCs) are primarily responsible for overseeing and implementing school health programs. They conduct regular health check-ups, immunizations, and health education in schools, ensuring the overall health and well-being of students. Hierarchical Structure of Health Centers in India : Level Name Function Population Coverage Staffing 1 Sub-Centers (SCs) (Option C ruled out) First point of contact for the community, providing basic healthcare services like immunization, maternal and child health, and health education. 5,000 people in plain areas, 3,000 in hilly/tribal areas 1 Female Health Worker (ANM) and 1 Male Health Worker 2 Primary Health Centers (PHCs) Provides integrated curative and preventive healthcare services for rural populations. Focuses on maternal and child health, immunization, and family planning. Serves 30,000 people Managed by a Medical Officer with supporting healthcare staff 3 Block Primary Health Center (Block PHC) Referral point for PHCs within the block, providing maternal and child health services, basic surgeries, and diagnostics. Serves a block population (typically 30,000–50,000 people) Medical Officer, Nurses, Lab Technicians 4 Community Health Centers (CHCs) Serves as a referral point for PHCs and provides specialized care. Serves 80,000 to 1,20,000 people Staffed with specialists (e.g., surgeons, obstetricians, pediatricians) 5 Sub-Divisional Hospitals (SDHs) (Option D ruled out) Provides more advanced care than PHCs or CHCs at the sub-divisional level, offering a broader range of medical services and treatments. Sub-divisional coverage Specialists, General Medical Practitioners 6 District Hospitals (Option B ruled out) Provide secondary care services and act as referral points for CHCs. Services include emergency care, surgeries, and specialized treatments. District-level coverage Specialists, General Medical Practitioners 7 Tertiary Care Hospitals Provide advanced medical care and specialized services, such as complex surgeries and treatment for rare conditions. Multi-district coverage Highly trained specialists in various medical fields Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 25, Page 636, 965 Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 27, Page 661

questions.question: The minimum requirements of a health worker job are given: should be a woman, a resident of the village, 25 to 45 years old, and have a formal education till 8th standard. What is the health worker called?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - ASHA worker It is a cadre of workers created under National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) in the year 2005. Only a slight difference has now been in the minimum educational qualification. It is now requested or asked, she should be a minimum 8th pass. ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) ASHA is a woman (married, divorced, or widowed) resident of the village, aged 25-45 years, with education up to 8th grade. Population Norm for ASHA The general norm is 1 ASHA per 1000 population. In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, this may be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation. Role and Responsibilities of ASHA Health Activist: Create awareness and provide information on health determinants, existing services, and the importance of health and family welfare. Counselor : Provide counseling on birth preparedness, safe delivery, and family planning. Mobilizer: Help the community access health services, such as immunizations, sanitation, and nutrition. Provider: Offer basic care for common illnesses and first-aid, and act as a depot for essential medications. Community Engagement: Work with village health committees and panchayats for planning and awareness. Specific Responsibilities of ASHA Promote health and sanitation practices. Advise on child care, immunization, and reproductive health. Assist with family planning and treatment of minor ailments. Mobilize pregnant women and children to health services Provide basic medical care and support for diarrhea, fever, and tuberculosis (under DOTS). Serve as a depot holder for essential drugs and medical supplies. Role and Integration with Anganwadi The Anganwadi worker helps guide ASHA, particularly in organizing Health Day activities, mobilizing village women and children, and promoting nutrition and health education. Role and Integration with ANMs (Auxiliary Nurse Midwives) ANMs guide ASHA in areas like immunization, safe pregnancy, and health education, and assist in organizing Health Days. ANMs also help with training and monitor ASHA's performance. Anganwadi worker (Option A): there is no maximum age limit (65 years at most) in most states. Nurse (Option B): the candidate should have a minimum of Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN) Midwife (Option C): the candidate should atleast have passed 12th standard exams. Most midwives have bachelor's degrees in health related fields. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive Medicine, 27th Edition, Page .989,990

questions.question: What are the primary referral centers in India's healthcare system?

options.A: Primary health centres and district hospitals
options.C: Community health centres and medical colleges
options.D: Sub-district hospitals and community health centres

questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - Sub-district hospitals and community health centres Sub-district centres are the first referral centres . They are the sub-district hospitals, district hospitals and community health centres. Level of Health Care Delivery System Rural Urban Tertiary Level of Health Care MC: Medical colleges SSH: Superspeciality hospitals Medical colleges SSH: Superspeciality hospitals Secondary Level of Health Care CHC: Community health center, SDH: Sub-district hospital DH: District hospital Urban CHC (u-CHC) Metrocity Non-metrocity Primary Level of Health Care SC: Sub-centers PHCs: Primary health centers Swasthya Chowki Urban PHC or Urban health center Grass Root Level Workers ASHA USHA Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5144115/

questions.question: Which of the following is not considered a pillar of primary health care?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Health education Health education, while not explicitly listed as a pillar of primary health care, is an essential component of comprehensive primary health care. It plays a vital role in empowering individuals and communities to make informed decisions about their health, prevent diseases, promote healthy behaviors, and enhance overall well-being. Four Pillars of Primary Health Care: Equitable distribution (Option D) Equitable distribution of health services irrespective of their socio-economic status. Intersectoral coordination (Option B) Involves collaboration from other sectors like agriculture, education, etc. Maintains good health. Appropriate technology (Option C) Use of technology that is accessible, affordable, and suitable for the community Eg: ORS VVM (Vaccine Vial Monitor): Heat sensitive label Shakir tape: Malnutrition grading Kangaroo mother care: Preterm care Community participation Ensure the participation of the community in planning, implementing and maintaining. For the promotion and maintenance of their health. Eg: ASHA workers are residents of the same community. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition Pg: 693-694

questions.question: Which of the following is the initial point of contact for individuals seeking medical assistance within a community?
questions.explanation: healthcare system, a sub-center serves as the community members' first point of contact when seeking medical attention. Incorrect Options : Option a: PHCs act as a referral link between the Sub-centres and higher-level healthcare facilities, like Community Health Centres (CHCs) and District Hospitals. Option b: PHCs and other lower-level healthcare facilities can be referred to CHCs, which are typically found in semi-urban or rural areas. Option d: A district hospital acts as a referral hub for primary care clinics (PHCs) and community health centers (CHCs), which are among the lower-level healthcare facilities.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the urban health care delivery system?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Subcenter Explanation: Sub-centers are primarily designed for rural healthcare delivery and are typically not part of the formal urban health infrastructure. Urban areas rely more on primary health centers (UPHCs) and Swasthya Chowkis instead. PHC (Option A): is incorrect because Primary Health Centers are part of the urban health care delivery system in certain cities for providing outpatient care and preventive services. CHC (Option B): is incorrect because Community Health Centers, although predominantly in rural areas, can also be established in semi-urban regions for specialty care. Swasthya chowki (Option C): is incorrect because these are urban healthcare units that play a role in healthcare delivery for densely populated urban slums. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 26, Page 502

questions.question: At which of the following centers are the records of eligible couples maintained?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Sub-centre Explanation: In the context of family planning and reproductive health services, sub-centres are responsible for maintaining records of eligible couples (those who are eligible for family planning services). The sub-centre is the lowest level of healthcare delivery and plays a key role in providing basic health services, including maternal and child health services, and managing family planning records. PHC (Option A): is incorrect because while PHCs provide a broader range of services than sub-centres , they do not typically maintain detailed records of eligible couples at the ground level. CHC (Option B): is incorrect because CHCs provide more specialized care and cover a larger area, but the maintenance of records for eligible couples is primarily managed at the sub-centre . District hospital (Option D): is incorrect because district hospitals focus on providing higher-level medical care and are not primarily responsible for maintaining family planning records for eligible couples, which is the role of sub-centres . Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 26, Page 990, 993, 1001, 1002.

questions.question: What is the number of the deliveries performed by Type-A PHC in a month?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Less than 20 Explanation: Type-A Primary Health Centers (PHCs) are typically small, rural healthcare facilities that are designed to serve a population in a limited geographical area. These centers typically handle fewer deliveries per month compared to higher-tier healthcare facilities. The number of deliveries is generally less than 20 per month at a Type-A PHC. 20 or above (Option B): is incorrect because Type-A PHCs usually manage fewer deliveries, with the number generally being less than 20 per month. Less than 30 (Option C): is incorrect because the Type-A PHC usually handles fewer than 20 deliveries, so 30 deliveries would typically be beyond its capacity. 30 or above (Option D): is incorrect because the capacity of a Type-A PHC is unlikely to handle 30 or more deliveries per month, which is more typical of larger health centers or hospitals. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 26, Page 994

questions.question: Which of the following should not be included in the school health service?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Doctor on premises Explanation: While it is important for schools to have access to healthcare services, having a doctor on premises is not a mandatory requirement for School Health Services . In many schools, a school health program is run by a nurse or a trained health worker , with doctors available for consultations when needed. The focus of school health services is on preventive care, routine health screenings, and maintaining health records. Having a doctor on-site is not a necessary component, as healthcare professionals can also be consulted through local health centers or clinics. Education of handicapped children (Option A): is incorrect because education of handicapped children is typically part of the school's inclusive education program, which is not directly linked to the medical services provided by the school health service, but is a separate educational initiative. Dental and eye health services (Option C): is incorrect because dental and eye health services are a key component of the school health service program, focusing on the prevention and treatment of common conditions like cavities, vision problems, and other health issues in children. School health records (Option D): is incorrect because maintaining school health records is an essential part of the school health service to monitor and track the health status, vaccinations, and any medical issues of students, ensuring proper care and follow-up when necessary. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 25, Page 663- 667.

questions.question: Which of the following is a technology-based surveillance system for tuberculosis (TB) in India?
questions.explanation: Tuberculosis Control Program (RNTCP) and the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) in India. It is a Health Management Information System (HMIS) - an online software for reporting & compliance with treatment. Incorrect Options: Nischay (Option B): Nischay Kits are home-based UPT testing kits provided free by Asha DOTS 99 (Option C): DOTS 99 is a toll-free number written below anti-TB tablets to ensure the continuity of the treatment. The patients in the continuation phase are expected to call the Toll-free number when they take the medicine. DOTS (Option D): Directly Observed Treatment Short course involves the direct observation of patients taking their TB medication during the intensive phase by a healthcare worker. Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 692

questions.question: Universal health coverage (UHC) means that all people and communities receive the quality health services they need, without financial hardship. Which of the following are the challenges to implementing UHC? income setting burden

options.A: Inequalities in the distribution, adequate support and access to quality assured products only in low
options.B: The purpose of UHC is to find a balance between countries' income, health provision and financial
options.C: To provide healthcare to everyone regardless of the countries' income
options.D: UHC only deals with financial aspect of health and cannot cover health provision to all

questions.explanation: services without financial hardship, irrespective of their country’s income. Challenges arise in low- and middle-income countries due to financial constraints, infrastructure gaps, and workforce shortages. Providing healthcare to everyone requires balancing resource allocation, government policies, and international support. Countries with lower incomes struggle with financing UHC, requiring external aid, innovative financing, and efficient healthcare systems. While UHC is an ideal goal, the feasibility of full coverage for all remains a major challenge globally. Universal Health Coverage (UHC)- A Global Challenge UHC is a key goal of global health initiatives, ensuring access to essential healthcare services without financial hardship for all individuals, regardless of their economic background. Principles of UHC Principle Explanation Equitable Access Everyone should receive healthcare regardless of socioeconomic status. Financial Protection Out-of-pocket expenses should not cause financial hardship. Quality Care Services should be effective, safe, and patient-centered. Sustainability Health systems should be designed for long-term viability. Challenges in Implementing UHC Challenge Reason Limited Financial Resources Low-income countries struggle to fund universal healthcare. Healthcare Workforce Shortage Lack of trained professionals, especially in rural areas. Infrastructure Gaps Inadequate hospitals, equipment, and medical supply chains. Political and Policy Barriers Differences in government commitment to UHC implementation. Global Strategies to Overcome UHC Challenges Strategy Description Innovative Financing Public-private partnerships, health insurance schemes, and global funding. Technology Integration Telemedicine and digital health solutions to expand access. International Support WHO and global organizations aiding low-income countries. "Inequalities in the distribution, adequate support, and access to quality-assured products only in low-income settings" (Option A): Incorrect because inequalities exist globally, not just in low-income settings. "The purpose of UHC is to find a balance between countries' income, health provision, and financial burden" (Option B): Incorrect because UHC aims to provide healthcare to all, not just balance economic factors. "UHC only deals with the financial aspect of health and cannot cover health provision to all" (Option D): Incorrect because UHC includes both financial protection and healthcare service expansion. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition Pg 824-825 https://nhm.gov.in/index1.php?lang=1&level=2&sublinkid=1048&lid=604

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the staff of an urban primary health center?
questions.explanation: Urban Primary Health Center (UPHC). There are 2 Multiskilled staff nurse in UPHC. Incorrect Options : Option a: 2 doctors In UPHC is correct statement. Option c: 1 lab technician In UPHC is correct statement. Option d: 1 pharmacist In UPHC is correct statement. Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding a primary healthcare center (PHC)?

options.A: There is 1 PHC per 30,000 population in plain areas
options.B: Type A PHC conducts <20 deliveries per month
options.C: Provides maternal and child health care, family planning and MTP

questions.explanation: healthcare system, and their primary role is to provide primary healthcare services, preventive care, and basic treatment. PHCs are not equipped to handle complex medical conditions or provide specialized care beyond primary healthcare. Incorrect Options: Option A. There is 1 PHC per 30,000 population in plain areas - This statement is generally accurate. the ratio of 1 PHC per 30,000 population in plain areas is a common guideline for healthcare infrastructure planning. Option B. Type A PHC conducts <20 deliveries per month - This statement is generally accurate. PHCs conduct a limited number of deliveries per month. Option C. Provides maternal and child health care, family planning, and MTP - This statement is accurate. PHCs play a vital role in providing maternal and child health services, family planning, and medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) services, among other primary healthcare services. Reference: .

questions.question: What is number of the deliveries performed by Type-A PHC in a month?
questions.explanation: Type-A Primary Health Center (PHC) in a month is fewer than 20. It is the correct answer Incorrect Options: Options B, C & D are incorrect

questions.question: What is the optimal approach to assess the injection practices of healthcare personnel?

options.A: Direct observation with a structured checklist
options.D: In-depth interview with the healthcare provider

questions.explanation: structured checklist is considered the best method to survey the injection practices of health workers. This approach involves trained observers directly observing the injection procedures and practices of healthcare providers and using a structured checklist to document their findings. Incorrect Options: Option B . Closed circuit camera surveillance: While closed circuit camera surveillance can provide visual recordings of injection practices, it may lack the ability to capture important details and nuances of the process. Option C . In-depth interview with the patient: While patient perspectives and experiences are valuable, relying solely on in-depth interviews with patients may not provide a comprehensive understanding of injection practices. Option D . In-depth interview with the healthcare provider: In-depth interviews may not capture the actual practices in a real-world setting and may be subject to recall bias or social desirability bias.

questions.question: Which of the following items is included in the concurrent list of the Indian Constitution?

options.B: Fishing and fisheries beyond territorial waters

questions.explanation: of the Indian Constitution means that both the central government and state governments have the authority to make laws and regulations to address this issue. It recognizes that ensuring food safety and preventing food adulteration is a shared responsibility between the central and state governments. Incorrect Options: Option B. Fishing and fisheries beyond territorial waters : This falls under the Union List, as the central government has exclusive jurisdiction over matters related to fishing and fisheries beyond territorial waters. Option C. Regulating labor in mines: This is also in the Union List, as the central government has the authority to regulate labor in mines. OptionD. Public health and sanitation : This subject is part of the State List, meaning that the state governments have the power to legislate on matters related to public health and sanitation.

questions.question: Which specific article in the Indian constitution grants the Right to Life to the residents of India?
questions.explanation: citizens of India. Article 21 states that "No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to the procedure established by law." This article is considered one of the fundamental rights guaranteed to every citizen of India. It ensures the protection of an individual's life and personal liberty from any unlawful or arbitrary deprivation. Incorrect Options: Option A: Article 11- Article 11 of the Indian Constitution does not confer any specific right. It relates to the power of the Parliament to regulate the rights of citizenship. Option C: Article 23- Article 23 prohibits human trafficking and forced labor, but it does not directly confer the Right to Life. Option D: Article 25- Article 25 guarantees the freedom of religion and the right to practice and propagate religion. It does not specifically confer the Right to Life.

questions.question: What is the population served by a single Primary Health Center (PHC) in the plains?
questions.explanation: is generally around 30,000. PHCs are the basic units of healthcare delivery in rural areas. Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the options below is established to facilitate health planning at the village level?

options.B: Village Health Planning and Management Committee
options.D: Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee

questions.explanation: health planning at the village level. It is a community-based committee responsible for addressing various health, sanitation, and nutrition-related issues within the village. The VHSNC is an important component of the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) in India and plays a crucial role in decentralized health planning and management. Incorrect Options: Option A , Panchayat Health Committee, is a term used in the context of local governance in India. Panchayat Health Committees are responsible for health-related functions within the Panchayati Raj system, which is the local self-government system in rural areas of India. While they play a role in health planning, they may not specifically focus on the village level. Option B, Village Health Planning and Management Committee, is not a commonly used term or a widely recognized committee in the context of health planning at the village level. Option C , Rogi Kalyan Samiti, is a committee typically found in hospitals and healthcare facilities in India. Rogi Kalyan Samiti focuses on patient welfare, quality improvement, and community participation in the functioning of healthcare facilities. It may not be specifically associated with health planning at the village level.

questions.question: Which of the following options is not encompassed within the Mental Health Care Act, 2017, as per the guidelines set by the WHO Mental Health Gap Action Programme?
questions.explanation: is not mentioned in the Mental Health Care Act, 2017. The Act primarily focuses on the rights of persons with mental illness, access to mental healthcare services, and the establishment of mental health authorities. Incorrect Options: Option B . Mobilization of resources: This aspect is important in ensuring the availability and accessibility of mental health services. The Mental Health Care Act, 2017, recognizes the importance of mobilizing resources to meet the mental health needs of the population. Option C . Social support: Social support plays a crucial role in promoting well-being and recovery. The Mental Health Care Act, 2017, recognizes the significance of social support in the rehabilitation and reintegration of persons with mental illness. Option D . Interpersonal therapy:While the Mental Health Care Act, 2017, emphasizes the provision of appropriate therapy and treatment, it does not specifically mention interpersonal therapy. Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the following vaccines has not been introduced to the immunization program in India?
questions.explanation: India. CDC recommends dengue vaccination for children 9 to16 years old, but only when they have been previously infected with dengue and living in areas where dengue is common. This previous infection should be confirmed by laboratory testing. Incorrect Options: Option A, C & D: . TT, Measles-Rubella and Rotavirus vaccines are included in national immunization program Reference: .
